body: @markusthoemmes thanks for making sure messages are now sent in a fixed sequence such that corresponding unit tests pass with any thread execution context and in any environment.

I'm having seconds thoughts on making the controller do more for every OPTIONS request, it would need to do a DB call to fetch the annotations. 
I proposed we table this one in a new issue to mull on it. 
I think one area to investigate is to see if the recommended way is to handle this before it reaches the controller like using apigateway 

For this issue we have two problems to fix pronto:
1. Add the explicit verbs to the response
2. Web actions should be able to receive OPTIONS http requests and be able to respond how ever it wants

What you think
The action is already fetched - so access to the annotation will not incur additional datastore overhead.

One proposal (P1):

Add two annotations: 

* `web-default-options`: true or false, and 
* `web-accept-methods`: {set of verbs}

Where default-options is true automatically (preserves behavior today for the most part) and responds with the following headers:
* `Access-Control-Allow-Origin`: `*` (all origins)
* `Access-Control-Allow-Methods`: `get, delete, post, put, head, options, patch`
* `Access-Control-Allow-Headers`: TBD??

If the `accept-methods` annotation is also specified, the methods listed in the set will supersede the default value for the `Access-Control-Allow-Methods` header.

Further, if `options` appears in the `accept-methods` annotation, then it overrides default-options (to false) and the action must implement its own response (and be prepared to invoke a receiving action twice (once for the options verb/preflight and then for the action request).

Alternative proposal (P2):

Add annotation to a web action for the default options response. This could be configured to specify all the desired values (not just the three noted above). 

* `web-options-headers`: { k -> v } where default is same set above
* `web-accept-methods`: {set of verbs}

For old times sake I tried to find an indentation error. Could'nt find one :+1: 😬 

@mrutkows are we moving scanCode out of this repo or do we keep adding stuff here?

You are right - this will result in a subject being throttled until the accounting is reset. This is a related proposed patch: https://github.com/rabbah/openwhisk/commit/c8a31abf51b5b00eceb6d82a833a3e96fc642c6b (although does not address this particular issue yet which requires a bit more refactoring).
This issue is a known defect and related to https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/issues/2118#issuecomment-292360083.
Will also need to update the wiki (pre commit hook tip): https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/wiki/Contributing:-Git-guidelines
Thanks for the info! Is there any reason that patch hasn't been accepted into the codebase yet?
@rabbah thanks for the reminder.
I haven't opened the pull request yet (It's part of several inter-related fixes). I expect to do that very soon.

I propose (P3)

By default controller response to http requests with method OPTIONS on web actions `/api/vi/web`
with the following response containing the following two headers:
```
Access-Control-Allow-Origin: * (all origins)
Access-Control-Allow-Methods: get, delete, post, put, head, options, patch
```

If user wants to handle the http requests for method OPTIONS then he can add an annotation
`web-options=true`

There might be other use cases to cover, but let's handle in a different issue.
P3 decouples the conflation of method-based routing and options response - good idea. I suggest `web-custom-options`: true or false, with false being the default (if missing).

```
> cat openwhisk/.git/hooks/pre-commit
#!/usr/bin/env bash
python /my/path/to//incubator-openwhisk-utilities/scancode/scanCode.py .
```

I may edit the page to add the pre-hook suggestion back.

Do we are on the same page to stop the bleed on this issue.
Is the hot standby mandatory? For local dev will there be one or two controllers?
@ddragosd heads up this will affect devtools.

To your question: `Is the hot standby mandatory? For local dev will there be one or two controllers?`

This PR just enables the ability to deploy a second controller on another machine. For all deployments on only one machine, there will be no hot-standby controller.
If you add a second host into the controller group into the hosts-file from ansible, only the first controller will be active. All other controllers will be hot-standby controllers.


Sounds good to me. For P3, an annotation of `web-custom-options: true` will require the user to respond to OPTIONS request with his or her custom CORS header. What about rejecting methods a `web-custom-options: true` web action does not support?

@michaelmarth This issue will enable such tooling you describe.

This allows to have the "the targeted OW instance" docker image to be use for both purposes to create the zip and also to run it.

Then the tooling can use the docker image to build. Adding git to the docker image will also be beneficial.

I'm hoping that's the end of most common dependencies to add to be able to have a single image for both purposes, and not go to a dual image one for build and another to run the action.
If we don't require the leading `/` then it will fix the problem we have with git-bash on Windows https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/issues/2313

Would this let me specify both a zip that get's send in /init, and also specify the docker image ?

Meaning let's say I have a few npm packages that are not included in the nodejs runtime, and the npm packages go above the 48MB, let's say 80MB.

Can I create a nodejs zip action call it nodejsaction.zip small without the npm pakcages.
Then create a new docker image that extends from openwhisk/nodejs6action with the only modification that I add more npm packages (80MB) to the image

Then do something in the cli like:
`wsk action create --kind native --docker csantanapr/fatnodejs myaction nodejsaction.zip`
Yes. There is an separate issue/feature request for that. The pr does both. I used native as the kind name rather than binary.

Everything should be able to use docker engine using docker CLI via socket file and no REST API connection

Yeah I think it would be a package instead, with an action per runtime, since the action would need the runtime anyway to compile, might as well be in the target language
```
whisk.system/compile/nodejs
whisk.system/compile/java
whisk.system/compile/swift
whisk.system/compile/python
```

There is no need for parameter kind

I would make the action accept two modes.
Give it a git info to get the source code from, or a zip

@pritidesai 
I don't follow why you do a `npm install` to create the zip to send to the action, that's what the action is suppose to do so any binaries from npm install are done in the correct runtime.

There should be specific parameters for each kind.
For example for nodejs, I might now that there is no binaries and is all pure js, so using webpack or something similar should be allow, maybe allow for a custom npm script like instead of npm install and zip you could run a npm run script.

@csantanapr Why should we use the CLI for everything? Using the REST API (which also works through the socket) is convenient in this case.

Note that we not only change the socket options but also enable user namespaces etc. for our CI.

@csantanapr could you add a description on what is failing in this case?
@style95 nope, it's good! I added two comments on typo/logging. If you could address those then I'm happy to get this in!

>
> +    def getServiceName(): String = {
> +        component + "_" + action
>
> Here service name is name of logical unit within context of action
> execution. Ex. invoker_activationinit or invoker_dockerpause etc. So
> combination of two is span name here.
>
ok, then I'd probably not use the word serviceName here, as usually in
zipkin serviceName is separate from spanName (especially in query). either
that or make a code doc saying serviceName isn't zipkin's serviceName

you may also want to consider tags (binary annotations) as that would
allow you to lookup by component. Ex the standard key for local
component in zipkin is "lc". Then your span names could choose to not
include the component part (more idiomatic)
Updated accordingly and all tests have been passed
